G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as the amount in controversy is less than $25,000 and the property is located within Worcester County.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as the amount in controversy is less than $25,000 and the property is located within Worcester County.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 and G.L. c. 239, as the leased premises are situated at 123 Elm Street, Worcester, Massachusetts 01603.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: Venue is proper in the Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 and G.L. c. 239, as the leased premises are situated at 123 Elm Street, Worcester, Massachusetts 01603.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7\u00a7 410.000 et seq..proposition: As part of the rental arrangement, Defendant, as landlord, was obligated to maintain the Premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. §§ 410.000 et seq., and to ensure Plaintiff’s right to quiet enjoyment as guaranteed by G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord “shall not, directly or indirectly, interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.”

105 C.M.R. \u00a7 410.550.proposition: Massachusetts law further requires landlords to maintain dwellings “free from infestation of insects, rodents, and other pests,” 105 C.M.R. § 410.550, and assigns the duty of extermination to the owner of any dwelling containing two or more units per 105 C.M.R. § 410.560(A).

105 C.M.R. \u00a7 410.560(A).proposition: Massachusetts law further requires landlords to maintain dwellings “free from infestation of insects, rodents, and other pests,” 105 C.M.R. § 410.550, and assigns the duty of extermination to the owner of any dwelling containing two or more units per 105 C.M.R. § 410.560(A).

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees that a tenant’s possession and use of rented premises will not be substantially interfered with by the acts or omissions of the landlord.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The court expressly frames the issue as a breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment based on substantial interference with the tenants’ use and enjoyment of the premises caused by noise from another space the landlords controlled. It emphasizes that the landlord’s liability arises from conditions that are the “natural and probable consequence” of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, showing that the covenant protects against substantial interference by the landlord’s acts or omissions. Thus the opinion directly supports the stated proposition.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Where the interference is not merely transient or trivial, a violation arises even without proof of malice.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s ‘quiet enjoyment’ clause and holds that malicious or specifically intentional conduct is not required. The court explains that, particularly after the 1973 amendment and in light of the common-law covenant, liability arises when the landlord’s conduct (here, at least reckless conduct) results in serious interference with quiet enjoyment; intent to disturb is expressly rejected as a prerequisite. Thus, a substantial, nontrivial interference can violate the statute without proof of malice.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Our analysis of the language and history of § 14… leads us to conclude that malicious intent is not necessary, and that the statute covers, at the least, reckless conduct such as Gem’s.… The common law background of § 14 also suggests that malicious intent is not a condition of liability… more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

*Doe v. Boston Housing Auth.*, 404 Mass..proposition: A continuing rodent infestation that the landlord fails to remedy after notice constitutes a substantial interference with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: A continuing rodent infestation that the landlord fails to remedy after notice constitutes a substantial interference with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address rodent infestations at all, nor does it interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14 in the context of vermin or similar sanitary code violations. Instead, it discusses whether a statutory lead paint violation, by itself and without proof of landlord fault, constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under § 14, and holds that at least negligent conduct with notice is required. While it notes that failure to repair known defects can violate § 14, rodents are not mentioned, so the case cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition about continuing rodent infestation.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Failure to comply with the State Sanitary Code constitutes evidence of interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly treats serious State Sanitary Code violations (here, failure to provide adequate heat and hot water) as rendering the premises uninhabitable, which in Massachusetts is the standard for breach of the warranty of habitability and for rent abatement. While the case is framed in terms of the implied warranty of habitability rather than explicitly as an action for "interference with quiet enjoyment" under G.L. c. 186, §14, the court repeatedly equates substantial Sanitary Code violations with failure to provide the habitable premises the tenant is paying for, making Code noncompliance evidence of the landlord’s breach of the tenant’s possessory rights. Thus, as authority that Sanitary Code noncompliance is evidence of impairment of the tenant’s statutory and contractual right to full use and enjoyment, the case provides substantial, though indirect, support.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … The State Sanitary Code, not such usage, provides the proper yardstick for measuring the landlord’s conduct. The Hemingway court removed the landlord’s duties under the Code from the realm of private ordering. … Those duties cannot be waived, bargained away, or qualified by customary practice.”

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.proposition: Failure to comply with the State Sanitary Code constitutes evidence of interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses State Sanitary Code violations in detail as part of the factual background and in connection with breach of the implied warranty of habitability and G.L. c. 93A, but it does not analyze or hold that failure to comply with the State Sanitary Code constitutes evidence of interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The quiet enjoyment counterclaim is mentioned only briefly and not tied doctrinally to sanitary code noncompliance. Thus, the case does not provide authoritative support for that specific legal proposition.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.relevant_excerpt: After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: (1) there was no functioning heating system; ... (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents. ... Later that month, the Boston inspection services department served Haddad with three separate notices of violations of State and city housing regulations related to the condition of Gonzalez's apartment. ... Based on the findings, as summarized above, the judge found in favor of Gonzalez on each of her counterclaims.

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s failure to adequately address the rodent infestation despite repeated notice from Plaintiff constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment recognized in Massachusetts common law.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case does interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does so specifically in the context of failure to provide heat, not rodent infestation. The holding establishes that a landlord’s failure to provide heat, regardless of financial inability, can violate § 14 and the covenant, but it does not address pests or infestation conditions at all. Using this case as authority for rodent‑infestation liability misstates its factual and doctrinal scope, even though its general quiet‑enjoyment principles might be analogically extended.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s failure to adequately address the rodent infestation despite repeated notice from Plaintiff constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment recognized in Massachusetts common law.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment and G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it holds that there was no breach because the landlord acted promptly once notified and substantially remedied the problems. The only infestation mentioned is ants, not rodents, and the court explicitly finds no interference with quiet enjoyment and no violation of the tenant’s statutory rights. Thus, this case does not support the proposition that a landlord’s failure to address a rodent infestation after repeated notice constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 or the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment; if anything, it illustrates when such a claim fails.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Similar to the warranty of habitability, during the rental of any residential premises, there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); G. L. c. 186, § 14. … Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions. … The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred. We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”
